|Title=Knowing the diagnostic criteria for a hypersecretory nodule
|Description=None

Hyperthyroidism can be induced by a single hypersecreting nodule (toxic adenoma) or by a toxic multinodular goitre (several hypersecreting nodules).

It is the leading cause of hyperthyroidism in the elderly.

The diagnostic criteria for a hypersecreting nodule or toxic multinodular goitre therefore include:

- Clinical: a thyrotoxicosis syndrome of variable intensity

- Hormonal profile: peripheral biological hyperthyroidism (low TSH) of variable intensity (= increased or normal T4 and/or T3).

- Ultrasound: a nodule or several nodules on thyroid ultrasound

- Scintigraphy: a single hyperfixing area with extinction of healthy thyroid parenchyma (if single adenoma = toxic adenoma) or alternating hot and cold fixation areas known as a checkerboard pattern (if multiple toxic nodules).

question.title: What is a diagnostic criterion for a hypersecreting nodule or toxic multinodular goitre?
question.description: The diagnostic criteria for a hypersecreting nodule or toxic multinodular goitre include:

option_a.title: A single hyperfixing area with normal TSH levels
option_a.description: A diagnostic criterion for a hypersecreting nodule or toxic multinodular goitre

option_b.title: A checkerboard pattern of hot and cold fixation areas on scintigraphy
option_b.description: A diagnostic criterion for a hypersecreting nodule or toxic multinodular goitre

option_c.title: A thyrotoxicosis syndrome of variable intensity
option_c.description: A diagnostic criterion for a hypersecreting nodule or toxic multinodular goitre

option_d.title: A single hyperfixing area with increased T4 and T3 levels
option_d.description: A diagnostic criterion for a hypersecreting nodule or toxic multinodular goitre

correct_option.title: c
correct_option.description: The correct letter of the option
